INF2SEPP CW3 Documentation

An analogy: The app we are creating will exist on only 1 device (and we don't need it to work on multiple devices). We can imagine it as being installed on a single self-service kiosk in a ticket booking office. In the beginning, there are no events and no accounts on the system. First, entertainment providers come to the kiosk, register for accounts, and manually enter details to create new events. Consumers can then come in, register at the kiosk, and make bookings. To cancel an event, the entertainment providers have to come in again, login to the kiosk and use it to cancel their event. On the other hand, this app does automatically sync with the EntertainmentProviderSystem, so when bookings are made outside this application, booked tickets become unavailable in the kiosk.

This documentation will help to guide your design. To better understand how this project is structured, you may want to read about the Command, State, Factory Method, and Singleton design patterns first.

The diagram on the left illustrates the package and class structure of the whole project - the coloured boxes are the packages, which have classes and enumerations within. The diagram on the right is a less pretty class diagram, but it contains all the fields, methods, and dependency arrows. These will be too small to see no matter how big your screen is, but if you right-click and choose "Open image in new tab", the full size variants should open.

The documentation links below explain in detail what each of the classes do. Your task is to replicate this project. Good luck!

Packages 
Package Description
command
The command package contains all the commands that implement the ICommand interface.
controller
The controller package contains the Context and Controller classes.
external
The external package contains interfaces for the external EntertainmentProviderSystem and PaymentSystem.
logging
The logging package contains the singleton Logger that logs events from anywhere in the application
model
The model package contains data structures corresponding to the classes and actors in the assignment specification
state
The state package contains all the classes that hold application state, like bookings, events, sponsorship requests, and users.
